natural problem:
Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$?
natural solution: Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.
Therefore, every face of $SPQR$ must have sides of lengths $18,$ $41,$ and $41$.

To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));

label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.

So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.

To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;

triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3" and area :: "(real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real)"
assumes h0 : "dist P Q = dist Q R = dist R P = dist S P = dist S Q = dist S R = 18 \<or> 41"
and h1 : "\<not> (dist P Q = dist Q R = dist R P \<or> dist S P = dist S Q = dist S R)"
shows  "area P Q R + area S P Q + area S Q R + area S R P = 1440"

 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3" and area :: "(real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real)"
assumes h0 : "dist P Q = dist Q R = dist R P = dist S P = dist S Q = dist S R = 18 \<or> 41"
and h1 : "\<not> (dist P Q = dist Q R = dist R P \<or> dist S P = dist S Q = dist S R)"
shows  "area P Q R + area S P Q + area S Q R + area S R P = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the total area of four triangles PQR, SPQ, SQR, and SRP. The distance between each pair of points is either 18 or 41, with the condition that all sides of triangle PQR are not the same length, and all distances from point S to points P, Q, and R are not the same length. The total area of the four triangles is 1440.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3" and area :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S \<notin> affine_hull {P, Q, R}"
and h1 : "\<forall> X Y. {X, Y} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> dist X Y = 18 \<or> dist X Y = 41"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> X Y Z. {X, Y, Z} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> area X Y Z = 18 * 18 * sqrt(3) / 4)"
and h3 : "\<not> (\<exists> X Y Z. {X, Y, Z} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> area X Y Z = 41 * 41 * sqrt(3) / 4)"
shows  "area P Q R + area P Q S + area P R S + area Q R S = 1440"

(* ### Problem

 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3" and area :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S \<notin> affine_hull {P, Q, R}"
and h1 : "\<forall> X Y. {X, Y} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> dist X Y = 18 \<or> dist X Y = 41"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> X Y Z. {X, Y, Z} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> area X Y Z = 18 * 18 * sqrt(3) / 4)"
and h3 : "\<not> (\<exists> X Y Z. {X, Y, Z} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> area X Y Z = 41 * 41 * sqrt(3) / 4)"
shows  "area P Q R + area P Q S + area P R S + area Q R S = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a tetrahedron with vertices P, Q, R, and S, the point S does not lie in the plane determined by P, Q, and R. Among any pair of distinct points from the set {P, Q, R, S}, the distance between them is either 18 or 41. However, there is no triangle formed by any combination of three points from the set {P, Q, R, S} that has an area equal to either $(18^2\sqrt{3})/4$ or $(41^2\sqrt{3})/4$. Find the sum of the areas of the four triangular faces of the tetrahedron (PQR, PQS, PRS, and QRS). The final answer is 1440.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes PQR :: "real poly" and S :: "real point" and area :: real
assumes h0 : "triangle PQR"
and h1 : "S \<notin> plane_of PQR"
and h2 : "\<forall>e. e \<in> edges (pyramid SPQR) \<longrightarrow> (length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41)"
and h3 : "\<forall>f. f \<in> faces (pyramid SPQR) \<longrightarrow> \<not> equilateral f"
shows  "surface_area (pyramid SPQR) = 1440"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440

 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.

 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes PQR :: "real poly" and S :: "real point" and area :: real
assumes h0 : "triangle PQR"
and h1 : "S \<notin> plane_of PQR"
and h2 : "\<forall>e. e \<in> edges (pyramid SPQR) \<longrightarrow> (length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41)"
and h3 : "\<forall>f. f \<in> faces (pyramid SPQR) \<longrightarrow> \<not> equilateral f"
shows  "surface_area (pyramid SPQR) = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a pyramid with base triangle PQR and vertex S not in the plane of PQR. All edges of the pyramid are either 18 or 41 units long, and none of the faces are equilateral triangles. Find the surface area of the pyramid. The final answer is 1440 square units.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes PQR_S :: "real polyhedron"
and S :: "point"
and SA :: "PQR_S \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "simplex PQR_S"
and h1 : "S \<notin> plane_of PQR_S"
and h2 : "\<forall>e \<in> edges PQR_S. length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41"
and h3 : "\<nexists> F \<in> faces PQR_S. equilateral F"
shows  "SA PQR_S = 1440"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.

theorem
fixes PQR_S :: "real polyhedron"
and S :: "point"
and SA :: "PQR_S \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "simplex PQR_S"
and h1 : "S \<notin> plane_of PQR_S"
and h2 : "\<forall>e \<in> edges PQR_S. length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41"
and h3 : "\<nexists> F \<in> faces PQR_S. equilateral F"
shows  "SA PQR_S = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Consider a polyhedron PQR_S with the following properties:

1. PQR_S is a simplex (a polyhedron with four vertices).
2. Point S is not on the plane of PQR_S.
3. All edges of PQR_S have a length of either 18 or 41.
4. There are no equilateral faces in PQR_S.

Find the surface area of PQR_S. The final answer is 1440.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real * real * real"
and edge_lengths :: "(real * real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
and surface_area :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P \<noteq> Q \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> (\<forall>T. T \<notin> {P, Q, R} \<longrightarrow> S \<noteq> T)"
and h1 : "\<forall>T1 T2. T1 \<noteq> T2 \<and> {T1, T2} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> edge_lengths T1 T2 \<in> {18, 41}"
and h2 : "\<forall>T1 T2 T3. {T1, T2, T3} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> edge_lengths T1 T2 \<noteq> edge_lengths T2 T3 \<or> edge_lengths T1 T3 \<noteq> edge_lengths T2 T3"
shows  "surface_area = 1440"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440

 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.

 To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));
 label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real * real * real"
and edge_lengths :: "(real * real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
and surface_area :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P \<noteq> Q \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> (\<forall>T. T \<notin> {P, Q, R} \<longrightarrow> S \<noteq> T)"
and h1 : "\<forall>T1 T2. T1 \<noteq> T2 \<and> {T1, T2} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> edge_lengths T1 T2 \<in> {18, 41}"
and h2 : "\<forall>T1 T2 T3. {T1, T2, T3} \<subseteq> {P, Q, R, S} \<longrightarrow> edge_lengths T1 T2 \<noteq> edge_lengths T2 T3 \<or> edge_lengths T1 T3 \<noteq> edge_lengths T2 T3"
shows  "surface_area = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A tetrahedron has four vertices P, Q, R, and S, where P, Q, and R are distinct, and S is not equal to any other vertex. The lengths of the edges connecting each pair of vertices are either 18 or 41 units. No two edges of equal length connect the same vertex. What is the surface area of the tetrahedron? The final answer is 1440 square units.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "dist P Q \<in> {18, 41}"
and h1 : "dist Q R \<in> {18, 41}"
and h2 : "dist R P \<in> {18, 41}"
and h3 : "dist S P \<in> {18, 41}"
and h4 : "dist S Q \<in> {18, 41}"
and h5 : "dist S R \<in> {18, 41}"
and h6 : "\<not> (\<forall> A B C. dist A B = dist B C \<and> dist B C = dist C A \<longrightarrow> A = B \<and> B = C)"
shows  "surface_area P Q R S = 1440"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440
 ### Proof

 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "dist P Q \<in> {18, 41}"
and h1 : "dist Q R \<in> {18, 41}"
and h2 : "dist R P \<in> {18, 41}"
and h3 : "dist S P \<in> {18, 41}"
and h4 : "dist S Q \<in> {18, 41}"
and h5 : "dist S R \<in> {18, 41}"
and h6 : "\<not> (\<forall> A B C. dist A B = dist B C \<and> dist B C = dist C A \<longrightarrow> A = B \<and> B = C)"
shows  "surface_area P Q R S = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a tetrahedron with vertices P, Q, R, and S, the distances between P and Q, Q and R, and R and P are either 18 or 41 units, and the distances between S and each of P, Q, and R are also either 18 or 41 units. Given that not all equidistant pairs of points are the same point, find the surface area of the tetrahedron. The final answer is 1440 square units.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and length_18 length_41 :: real
and surface_area :: real
assumes h0 : "triangle PQR"
and h1 : "S \<notin> affine hull {P, Q, R}"
and h2 : "\<forall>u v. u \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> v \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> u \<noteq> v \<longrightarrow> (dist u v = length_18 \<or> dist u v = length_41)"
and h3 : "\<forall>u v w. u \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> v \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> w \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> u \<noteq> v \<and> v \<noteq> w \<and> u \<noteq> w \<longrightarrow> triangle u v w \<and> \<not> equilateral u v w"
and h4 : "length_18 = 18 \<and> length_41 = 41"
and h5 : "surface_area = (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (P, Q, R) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, P, Q) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, Q, R) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, R, P)"
shows  "surface_area = 1440"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440
 ### Proof
 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.
 Therefore, every face of $SPQR$ must have sides of lengths $18,$ $41,$ and $41$.
 To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));
 label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and length_18 length_41 :: real
and surface_area :: real
assumes h0 : "triangle PQR"
and h1 : "S \<notin> affine hull {P, Q, R}"
and h2 : "\<forall>u v. u \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> v \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> u \<noteq> v \<longrightarrow> (dist u v = length_18 \<or> dist u v = length_41)"
and h3 : "\<forall>u v w. u \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> v \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> w \<in> {P, Q, R, S} \<and> u \<noteq> v \<and> v \<noteq> w \<and> u \<noteq> w \<longrightarrow> triangle u v w \<and> \<not> equilateral u v w"
and h4 : "length_18 = 18 \<and> length_41 = 41"
and h5 : "surface_area = (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (P, Q, R) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, P, Q) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, Q, R) + (\<lambda>(u, v, w). 0.5 * dist u v * dist u w * sin (angle u v w)) (S, R, P)"
shows  "surface_area = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a tetrahedron with vertices P, Q, R, and S. The triangle PQR is not equilateral, and vertex S is not in the same plane as triangle PQR. There are two distinct edge lengths in the tetrahedron: 18 and 41. None of the triangles formed by any combination of three vertices of the tetrahedron are equilateral. Find the surface area of the tetrahedron, given that it can be calculated using the sum of the areas of the four triangular faces, each of which can be computed as $0.5 * dist(u,v) * dist(u,w) * sin(angle(u,v,w))$ for vertices u, v, and w. The final answer is 1440.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A_PQR A_PSQ A_PRS A_QRS :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>e. e \<in> {SP, SQ, SR, PQ, PR, QR} \<longrightarrow> length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. A \<in> {A_PQR, A_PSQ, A_PRS, A_QRS} \<longrightarrow> \<not> equilateral A"
shows  "A_PQR + A_PSQ + A_PRS + A_QRS = 1440"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440
 ### Proof
 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.
 Therefore, every face of $SPQR$ must have sides of lengths $18,$ $41,$ and $41$.
 To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));
 label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes A_PQR A_PSQ A_PRS A_QRS :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>e. e \<in> {SP, SQ, SR, PQ, PR, QR} \<longrightarrow> length e = 18 \<or> length e = 41"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. A \<in> {A_PQR, A_PSQ, A_PRS, A_QRS} \<longrightarrow> \<not> equilateral A"
shows  "A_PQR + A_PSQ + A_PRS + A_QRS = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a geometry problem, there are four triangles: $PQR$, $PSQ$, $PRS$, and $QRS$. Each side of the triangles has a length of either 18 or 41 units. None of the triangles are equilateral. Find the total area of the four triangles, given that the sum is 1440 square units.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and area_triangle :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
and surface_area_pyramid :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. dist a b = 18 \<or> dist a b = 41"
and h1 : "distinct [P, Q, R, S]"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> dist a b = dist b c \<and> dist a c = dist a b)"
and h3 : "surface_area_pyramid P Q R S = 
          area_triangle P Q R + area_triangle P Q S + area_triangle P R S + area_triangle Q R S"
shows  "surface_area_pyramid P Q R S = 1440"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440
 ### Proof
 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.
 Therefore, every face of $SPQR$ must have sides of lengths $18,$ $41,$ and $41$.
 To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));
 label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and area_triangle :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
and surface_area_pyramid :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. dist a b = 18 \<or> dist a b = 41"
and h1 : "distinct [P, Q, R, S]"
and h2 : "\<not> (\<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> dist a b = dist b c \<and> dist a c = dist a b)"
and h3 : "surface_area_pyramid P Q R S = 
          area_triangle P Q R + area_triangle P Q S + area_triangle P R S + area_triangle Q R S"
shows  "surface_area_pyramid P Q R S = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A pyramid has vertices P, Q, R, and S. The distances between any two of its vertices are either 18 or 41 units. The pyramid does not have any equilateral triangles formed by any three of its vertices. The surface area of the pyramid is equal to the sum of the areas of the triangles formed by its vertices: PQR, PQS, PRS, and QRS. What is the surface area of the pyramid? The final answer is 1440 square units.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and A :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real" (infix "\<bullet>" 70) -- "dot product"
and B :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3" (infix "\<times>" 70) -- "cross product"
and len :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> v. len v = sqrt (v \<bullet> v)"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b c. area a b c = 0.5 * len ((b - a) \<times> (c - a))"
and h2 : "len (P - Q) = 18 \<or> len (P - Q) = 41"
and h3 : "len (P - R) = 18 \<or> len (P - R) = 41"
and h4 : "len (P - S) = 18 \<or> len (P - S) = 41"
and h5 : "len (Q - R) = 18 \<or> len (Q - R) = 41"
and h6 : "len (Q - S) = 18 \<or> len (Q - S) = 41"
and h7 : "len (R - S) = 18 \<or> len (R - S) = 41"
and h8 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area P Q S"
and h9 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area P R S"
and h10 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area Q R S"
and h11 : "area P Q S \<noteq> area P R S"
and h12 : "area P Q S \<noteq> area Q R S"
and h13 : "area P R S \<noteq> area Q R S"
shows  "area P Q R + area P Q S + area P R S + area Q R S = 1440"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle PQR$ be a triangle in the plane, and let $S$ be a point outside the plane of $\triangle PQR$, so that $SPQR$ is a pyramid whose faces are all triangles.

Suppose that every edge of $SPQR$ has length $18$ or $41$, but no face of $SPQR$ is equilateral. Then what is the surface area of $SPQR$? The final Answer is 1440
 ### Proof
 Since all edges of pyramid $SPQR$ have length $18$ or $41$, each triangular face must be isosceles: either $18$-$18$-$41$ or $18$-$41$-$41$. But the first of these two sets of side lengths violates the triangle inequality, since $18+18<41$.
 Therefore, every face of $SPQR$ must have sides of lengths $18,$ $41,$ and $41$.
 To find the area of each face, we draw an $18$-$41$-$41$ triangle with altitude $h$: [asy] size(4cm); pair a=(0,40); pair b=(-9,0); pair c=(9,0); pair o=(0,0); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); draw(a--b--c--a); draw(a--o,dashed); draw(rightanglemark(a,o,c,60));
 label("$h$",(a+2*o)/3,SE); label("$41$",(a+c)/2,E); label("$9$",(o+c)/2,N); label("$41$",(a+b)/2,W); label("$9$",(o+b)/2,N); [/asy] Since the triangle is isosceles, we know the altitude bisects the base (as marked above).
 By the Pythagorean theorem, we have $9^2+h^2=41^2$ and thus $h=40$.
 So, the triangle has area $\frac 12\cdot 18\cdot 40 = 360$. The surface area of pyramid $SPQR$ is made up of four such triangles, so it amounts to $4\cdot 360 = \boxed{1440}$. ${\bf Remark. }$  One might wonder whether a pyramid with the properties enumerated in the problem actually exists.
 The answer is yes!
 To form such a pyramid, imagine attaching two $18$-$41$-$41$ triangles (like that in the diagram) along their short edges, so that the triangles are free to rotate around that hinge: [asy] import three;
 triple a=(9,0,0); triple b=-a; triple c=(0,sqrt(1519),-9); triple d=(0,sqrt(1519),9); dot(a); dot(b); dot(c); dot(d); draw(surface(a--b--c--cycle),orange,nolight); draw(b--c--a); draw(surface(a--b--d--cycle),yellow,nolight);
 draw(b--d--a--b); draw(c--d,dashed); [/asy] Now you can adjust the distance between the two "free" vertices (the dotted line in the diagram above) so that it is $18$.
 Adding that edge to the diagram and filling in, we have a pyramid with the desired properties.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R S :: "real^3"
and A :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real" (infix "\<bullet>" 70) -- "dot product"
and B :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3" (infix "\<times>" 70) -- "cross product"
and len :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
and area :: "real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real^3 \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> v. len v = sqrt (v \<bullet> v)"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b c. area a b c = 0.5 * len ((b - a) \<times> (c - a))"
and h2 : "len (P - Q) = 18 \<or> len (P - Q) = 41"
and h3 : "len (P - R) = 18 \<or> len (P - R) = 41"
and h4 : "len (P - S) = 18 \<or> len (P - S) = 41"
and h5 : "len (Q - R) = 18 \<or> len (Q - R) = 41"
and h6 : "len (Q - S) = 18 \<or> len (Q - S) = 41"
and h7 : "len (R - S) = 18 \<or> len (R - S) = 41"
and h8 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area P Q S"
and h9 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area P R S"
and h10 : "area P Q R \<noteq> area Q R S"
and h11 : "area P Q S \<noteq> area P R S"
and h12 : "area P Q S \<noteq> area Q R S"
and h13 : "area P R S \<noteq> area Q R S"
shows  "area P Q R + area P Q S + area P R S + area Q R S = 1440"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given four points P, Q, R, S in three-dimensional space, the distances between any two points are either 18 or 41 units. The area of a triangle formed by any three points is calculated as 0.5 times the length of the cross product of the vectors defined by the vertices of the triangle. No two triangles formed by these four points have the same area. Find the sum of the areas of the four triangles PQR, PQS, PRS, and QRS. The final answer is 1440 units squared.
